events.title: Swallowed by a Wolf, Ingenious Trickery, and Miraculous Rescue
detailed_summary: Tom immediately began working to free himself from the cow's stomach, a task that proved difficult.
Just as he had managed to create enough space to get his head out, another misfortune befell him.
A hungry wolf appeared, swallowed the entire stomach with Tom inside in a single gulp, and then ran off.
Tom, however, remained undaunted. Believing the wolf might enjoy a conversation, he called out, offering to show his 'good friend' a fantastic treat.
When the wolf inquired about its location, Tom described his own father's house.

He provided specific instructions on how the wolf could crawl through the drain into the kitchen and then into the pantry, where it would find an abundance of delicacies like cakes, ham, beef, and more.
The wolf needed no second invitation and that very night, it went to the house, entered as Tom had described, and feasted to its satisfaction.
When it had eaten its fill and tried to leave, it discovered it had consumed so much that it could no longer fit back through the drain.
This was precisely what Tom had anticipated. He then began to shout and make as much noise as possible.
The wolf begged him to be quiet, warning that he would wake everyone in the house.
Tom retorted defiantly, stating that since the wolf had enjoyed its frolic, he now intended to be merry himself, and he continued to sing and shout at the top of his lungs.
The woodman and his wife, awakened by the commotion, peeked through a crack in the door and were terrified to see a wolf.
The woodman fetched his axe, and his wife a scythe.
The woodman instructed his wife to stay behind and, after he had struck the wolf on the head, she was to cut it open with the scythe.
Tom heard these instructions and cried out, 'Father, father! I am here, the wolf has swallowed me.'
His father, overjoyed, exclaimed that they had found their dear child again and told his wife not to use the scythe for fear of harming Tom.
The woodman then aimed a powerful blow at the wolf's head, killing it instantly.
Once the wolf was dead, they cut open its body and freed Tommy.
The father expressed the great fears they had experienced for Tom's safety.
Tom replied that he felt he had traveled all over the world in various ways since they last parted, and he was now very glad to be home and breathe fresh air again.
When his father asked where he had been, Tom recounted his adventures: in a mouse-hole, a snail-shell, down a cow's throat, and inside a wolf's belly, yet he had returned safe and sound.

Tom, however, was still not disheartened; and thinking the wolf would not dislike having some chat with him as he was going along, he called out, ‘My good friend, I can show you a famous treat.’ ‘Where’s that?’ said the wolf. ‘In such and such a house,’ said Tom, describing his own father’s house. ‘You can crawl through the drain into the kitchen and then into the pantry, and there you will find cakes, ham, beef, cold chicken, roast pig, apple-dumplings, and everything that your heart can wish.’
The wolf did not want to be asked twice; so that very night he went to the house and crawled through the drain into the kitchen, and then into the pantry, and ate and drank there to his heart’s content. As soon as he had had enough he wanted to get away; but he had eaten so much that he could not go out by the same way he came in.
This was just what Tom had reckoned upon; and now he began to set up a great shout, making all the noise he could. ‘Will you be easy?’ said the wolf; ‘you’ll awaken everybody in the house if you make such a clatter.’ ‘What’s that to me?’ said the little man; ‘you have had your frolic, now I’ve a mind to be merry myself’; and he began, singing and shouting as loud as he could.
The woodman and his wife, being awakened by the noise, peeped through a crack in the door; but when they saw a wolf was there, you may well suppose that they were sadly frightened; and the woodman ran for his axe, and gave his wife a scythe. ‘Do you stay behind,’ said the woodman, ‘and when I have knocked him on the head you must rip him up with the scythe.’ Tom heard all this, and cried out, ‘Father, father! I am here, the wolf has swallowed me.’ And his father said, ‘Heaven be praised! we have found our dear child again’; and he told his wife not to use the scythe for fear she should hurt him. Then he aimed a great blow, and struck the wolf on the head, and killed him on the spot! and when he was dead they cut open his body, and set Tommy free. ‘Ah!’ said the father, ‘what fears we have had for you!’ ‘Yes, father,’ answered he; ‘I have travelled all over the world, I think, in one way or other, since we parted; and now I am very glad to come home and get fresh air again.’ ‘Why, where have you been?’ said his father. ‘I have been in a mouse-hole—and in a snail-shell—and down a cow’s throat—and in the wolf’s belly; and yet here I am again, safe and sound.’

detailed_summary: His parents declared that now he was back, they would not sell him again for all the riches in the world.

So Master Thumb stayed at home with his father and mother, living in peace.
Although he had been a great traveller, had experienced many remarkable things, and enjoyed recounting his adventures, he always acknowledged that, ultimately, there is no place like home.

events.title: The Miller's Impossible Boast and the King's Cruel Demand
detailed_summary: A miller, residing near a wood and a stream, had a very beautiful, shrewd, and clever daughter.
The miller, filled with pride, boasted to the king of the land that his daughter possessed the ability to spin straw into gold.

He led her to a chamber in his palace filled with a large quantity of straw, provided her with a spinning-wheel, and issued a dire ultimatum.
The king commanded her to transform all the straw into gold before the morning, threatening her life if she failed.
The poor maiden protested in vain, explaining that her father's statement was merely a foolish boast and that she lacked any such skill.
Despite her pleas, the chamber door was locked, leaving her alone and in despair.

events.title: Rumpelstiltskin Revealed and His Furious Demise
detailed_summary: Upon hearing the name 'Rumpelstiltskin', the queen leaped with joy.

The nurse stood beside her, holding the baby as if fully prepared to surrender him.
The little man began to chuckle, anticipating taking the child to his woodland hut.
He then triumphantly asked, 'Now, lady, what is my name?'
The queen playfully offered incorrect guesses such as 'Is it JOHN?' and 'Is it TOM?', then 'Is it JEMMY?', all of which he denied.
Then, with a sly demeanor, she inquired, 'Can your name be RUMPELSTILTSKIN?'
The little man, utterly astonished and enraged, cried out that a witch must have revealed his name.
In his fury, he stamped his right foot so forcefully into the floor that it became stuck, requiring him to use both hands to pull it free.
He then departed as swiftly as possible, while the nurse laughed, the baby cooed, and the entire court jeered at him for his fruitless efforts.
They mockingly wished him a good morning and a merry feast, addressing him as 'Mr RUMPLESTILTSKIN!'

events.title: Guest Preparation and Gretel's First Indulgence
detailed_summary: The master instructs Gretel to prepare two fowls with great care for an evening guest.
Gretel prepares the chickens, puts them on a spit, and sets them by the fire to roast as evening approaches.
As the fowls are nearly cooked, the guest has not yet shown up.
Gretel warns her master that the fowls must be removed from the fire soon to prevent them from being overcooked and that it would be a shame if they weren't eaten at their peak juiciness.
The master decides to personally go and bring the guest.
With the master gone, Gretel feels hot and thirsty from being near the fire and contemplates that the guest's arrival is uncertain.
She decides to go to the cellar for a drink.
She pours herself wine, blesses it, takes a substantial drink, and then another, believing wine's enjoyment should be continuous.

events.text_segment: It came to pass that the master one day said to her: ‘Gretel, there is a guest coming this evening; prepare me two fowls very daintily.’ ‘I will see to it, master,’ answered Gretel. She killed two fowls, scalded them, plucked them, put them on the spit, and towards evening set them before the fire, that they might roast. The fowls began to turn brown, and were nearly ready, but the guest had not yet arrived. Then Gretel called out to her master: ‘If the guest does not come, I must take the fowls away from the fire, but it will be a sin and a shame if they are not eaten the moment they are at their juiciest.’ The master said: ‘I will run myself, and fetch the guest.’ When the master had turned his back, Gretel laid the spit with the fowls on one side, and thought: ‘Standing so long by the fire there, makes one sweat and thirsty; who knows when they will come? Meanwhile, I will run into the cellar, and take a drink.’ She ran down, set a jug, said: ‘God bless it for you, Gretel,’ and took a good drink, and thought that wine should flow on, and should not be interrupted, and took yet another hearty draught.

The young wife verbally reprimanded him for this, but he only responded with a sigh of resignation.
As a replacement, they provided him with a cheap wooden bowl from which he had to eat his meals.

events.title: The Peasant's Makeshift Soothsayer and the Unveiling of a Hidden Feast
detailed_summary: The peasant and his wife finally possessed the cow they had long desired but lacked food for it, compelling them to slaughter it soon after.
They preserved the meat by salting it, and the peasant intended to sell the cow's skin in town to finance the purchase of a new calf.
En route, he passed a mill where he found a raven with injured wings; moved by pity, he took the raven and wrapped it in the cow skin he was carrying.
Severe weather, including a storm of rain and wind, prevented him from continuing his journey, forcing him to turn back to the mill to ask for shelter.
The miller's wife, who was alone in the house, allowed him to rest on some straw and provided him with a piece of bread and cheese.
The peasant ate and then lay down with the skin containing the raven beside him, while the miller's wife assumed he was tired and asleep.
Shortly thereafter, the parson arrived, and the miller's wife welcomed him warmly, stating that since her husband was out, they could enjoy a feast together.
The peasant, overhearing their plans for a feast, felt irritated that he had to be content with just bread and cheese.
The miller's wife then served a spread of four different items: roast meat, salad, cakes, and wine for herself and the parson.
Just as they were preparing to eat, a knock was heard at the door.

The miller's wife, alarmed, exclaimed it was her husband and quickly concealed the food items: the roast meat in the tiled stove, the wine under the pillow, the salad on the bed, and the cakes under the bed. She also hid the parson in a closet on the porch.
She then opened the door for her husband, remarking on his timely return and the severity of the storm.
The miller noticed the peasant on the straw and inquired about his presence.
His wife explained that the poor man had sought refuge from the storm and she had offered him some bread, cheese, and a place on the straw.
The miller expressed no objection and asked his wife to quickly prepare something for him to eat.
The wife claimed she only had bread and cheese.
The husband, stating he was content with anything, invited the peasant to join him in eating more bread and cheese.
The peasant accepted the offer and ate with the miller.
Afterwards, the miller saw the skin lying on the ground and asked what the peasant had in it.
The peasant replied that he had a soothsayer inside the skin.
When the miller asked if it could tell his fortune, the peasant affirmed, adding that it reveals four things but keeps a fifth to itself.
Intrigued, the miller requested a prophecy.
The peasant pinched the raven's head, causing it to croak.
The peasant then 'interpreted' the first prophecy: there was wine hidden under the pillow. The miller searched and found the wine.
The peasant made the raven croak again and 'interpreted' the second prophecy: roast meat was hidden in the tiled stove. The miller found it.
A third croak 'revealed' salad on the bed, which the miller also discovered.
Finally, the peasant elicited another croak and 'prophesied' that cakes were under the bed. The miller found these as well.

But as the weather grew so bad and there was a storm of rain and wind, he could go no farther, and turned back to the mill and begged for shelter. The miller’s wife was alone in the house, and said to the peasant: ‘Lay yourself on the straw there,’ and gave him a slice of bread and cheese. The peasant ate it, and lay down with his skin beside him, and the woman thought: ‘He is tired and has gone to sleep.’ In the meantime came the parson; the miller’s wife received him well, and said: ‘My husband is out, so we will have a feast.’ The peasant listened, and when he heard them talk about feasting he was vexed that he had been forced to make shift with a slice of bread and cheese. Then the woman served up four different things, roast meat, salad, cakes, and wine.
Just as they were about to sit down and eat, there was a knocking outside. The woman said: ‘Oh, heavens! It is my husband!’ she quickly hid the roast meat inside the tiled stove, the wine under the pillow, the salad on the bed, the cakes under it, and the parson in the closet on the porch. Then she opened the door for her husband, and said: ‘Thank heaven, you are back again! There is such a storm, it looks as if the world were coming to an end.’ The miller saw the peasant lying on the straw, and asked, ‘What is that fellow doing there?’ ‘Ah,’ said the wife, ‘the poor knave came in the storm and rain, and begged for shelter, so I gave him a bit of bread and cheese, and showed him where the straw was.’ The man said: ‘I have no objection, but be quick and get me something to eat.’ The woman said: ‘But I have nothing but bread and cheese.’ ‘I am contented with anything,’ replied the husband, ‘so far as I am concerned, bread and cheese will do,’ and looked at the peasant and said: ‘Come and eat some more with me.’ The peasant did not require to be invited twice, but got up and ate. After this the miller saw the skin in which the raven was, lying on the ground, and asked: ‘What have you there?’ The peasant answered: ‘I have a soothsayer inside it.’ ‘Can he foretell anything to me?’ said the miller. ‘Why not?’ answered the peasant: ‘but he only says four things, and the fifth he keeps to himself.’ The miller was curious, and said: ‘Let him foretell something for once.’ Then the peasant pinched the raven’s head, so that he croaked and made a noise like krr, krr. The miller said: ‘What did he say?’ The peasant answered: ‘In the first place, he says that there is some wine hidden under the pillow.’ ‘Bless me!’ cried the miller, and went there and found the wine. ‘Now go on,’ said he. The peasant made the raven croak again, and said: ‘In the second place, he says that there is some roast meat in the tiled stove.’ ‘Upon my word!’ cried the miller, and went thither, and found the roast meat. The peasant made the raven prophesy still more, and said: ‘Thirdly, he says that there is some salad on the bed.’ ‘That would be a fine thing!’ cried the miller, and went there and found the salad. At last the peasant pinched the raven once more till he croaked, and said: ‘Fourthly, he says that there are some cakes under the bed.’ ‘That would be a fine thing!’ cried the miller, and looked there, and found the cakes.

The merchant, intrigued, said, “Will it tell my fortune?”  

The peasant nodded, and the raven, feeling the movement, croaked, “Krr! Krr!”  

“What does that mean?” the merchant asked eagerly.  

The peasant, quick-witted, replied, “It says you have stolen money hidden beneath your hearth at home.”  

The merchant turned pale, for it was true. Fearing the peasant would expose him, he offered a bag of gold in exchange for the raven. The peasant agreed, delighted with his luck, and continued on his way.  

Now richer than he had ever been, the peasant returned home to his wife, who marveled at the gold. “How did you get this?” she asked.  

“I traded the cow’s hide for a raven, and the raven for gold,” he said, laughing.  

But their joy was short-lived, for the greedy merchant soon realized he had been tricked. Furious, he went to the peasant’s house and demanded his money back.  

“I have no money,” the peasant lied. “It was all a jest.”  

The merchant, not believing him, dragged the peasant before the judge. When questioned, the peasant repeated his tale, adding, “The raven spoke the truth, but the merchant feared its words.”  

The judge, though skeptical, could not prove otherwise, and the peasant was allowed to keep the gold.  

Now the peasant and his wife lived comfortably for a time, but the merchant, still seething with anger, plotted revenge. One night, he crept into their yard and stole their remaining livestock.  

The next morning, the peasant discovered the theft and knew at once who was responsible. He went to the merchant’s house and shouted, “Return what you have taken, or I shall make you regret it!”  

The merchant laughed. “Prove it was me!”  

The peasant, undeterred, went to the judge again. “This man has stolen from me,” he declared.  

But without proof, the judge could do nothing. The peasant, however, was not so easily defeated. That night, he crept into the merchant’s barn and took back his animals, leaving behind a note: *As you have done to me, so I have done to you.*  

When the merchant found the note, he was enraged but dared not complain, for fear his own theft would be exposed.  

From then on, the little peasant and his wife lived wisely, guarding their wealth and never trusting those who sought to deceive them. And though they had begun with nothing, their cleverness and courage brought them prosperity in the end.

There was once a man called Frederick: he had a wife whose name was Catherine, and they had not long been married. One day Frederick said. ‘Kate! I am going to work in the fields; when I come back I shall be hungry so let me have something nice cooked, and a good draught of ale.’ ‘Very well,’ said she, ‘it shall all be ready.’ When dinner-time drew nigh, Catherine took a nice steak, which was all the meat she had, and put it on the fire to fry. The steak soon began to look brown, and to crackle in the pan; and Catherine stood by with a fork and turned it: then she said to herself, ‘The steak is almost ready, I may as well go to the cellar for the ale.’ So she left the pan on the fire and took a large jug and went into the cellar and tapped the ale cask. The beer ran into the jug and Catherine stood looking on. At last it popped into her head, ‘The dog is not shut up—he may be running away with the steak; that’s well thought of.’ So up she ran from the cellar; and sure enough the rascally cur had got the steak in his mouth, and was making off with it.
Away ran Catherine, and away ran the dog across the field: but he ran faster than she, and stuck close to the steak. ‘It’s all gone, and “what can’t be cured must be endured”,’ said Catherine. So she turned round; and as she had run a good way and was tired, she walked home leisurely to cool herself.
Now all this time the ale was running too, for Catherine had not turned the cock; and when the jug was full the liquor ran upon the floor till the cask was empty. When she got to the cellar stairs she saw what had happened. ‘My stars!’ said she, ‘what shall I do to keep Frederick from seeing all this slopping about?’ So she thought a while; and at last remembered that there was a sack of fine meal bought at the last fair, and that if she sprinkled this over the floor it would suck up the ale nicely. ‘What a lucky thing,’ said she, ‘that we kept that meal! we have now a good use for it.’ So away she went for it: but she managed to set it down just upon the great jug full of beer, and upset it; and thus all the ale that had been saved was set swimming on the floor also. ‘Ah! well,’ said she, ‘when one goes another may as well follow.’ Then she strewed the meal all about the cellar, and was quite pleased with her cleverness, and said, ‘How very neat and clean it looks!’
At noon Frederick came home. ‘Now, wife,’ cried he, ‘what have you for dinner?’ ‘O Frederick!’ answered she, ‘I was cooking you a steak; but while I went down to draw the ale, the dog ran away with it; and while I ran after him, the ale ran out; and when I went to dry up the ale with the sack of meal that we got at the fair, I upset the jug: but the cellar is now quite dry, and looks so clean!’ ‘Kate, Kate,’ said he, ‘how could you do all this?’ Why did you leave the steak to fry, and the ale to run, and then spoil all the meal?’ ‘Why, Frederick,’ said she, ‘I did not know I was doing wrong; you should have told me before.’

**Frederick and Catherine**  

There was once a man called Frederick: he had a wife whose name was Catherine, and they had not long been married. One day, Frederick said to her, "Catherine, I must go out into the fields to work. When I return, I should like something good to eat—something hot and hearty."  

Catherine, eager to please her husband, replied, "Very well, dear Frederick. I shall prepare a fine meal for you."  

As soon as Frederick left, Catherine set to work. She took a fine piece of bacon from the pantry and placed it in the frying pan over the fire. While the bacon sizzled, she stood by, watching it carefully. But as she did so, she began to think, *The bacon will be ready soon, but perhaps I should fetch some wine from the cellar to go with it.*  

So she hurried down to the cellar, leaving the pan on the fire. But as she was filling the jug with wine, she heard a loud *thump!* from upstairs. Startled, she rushed back up—only to find that their mischievous dog had snatched the bacon from the pan and was running off with it!  

"Oh, wicked beast!" cried Catherine, chasing after the dog. But the dog was too quick, darting out the door and into the fields. Catherine ran after him, waving a spoon, but soon she lost sight of him.  

Exhausted, she sat down on a rock to catch her breath. As she did, she thought, *What will Frederick say when he comes home and finds no meal ready? I must think of something!*  

Looking around, she noticed that the field was full of ripe wheat. *Ah!* she thought. *If I gather some wheat, I can bake fresh bread instead!* So she set to work, cutting stalks of wheat with her apron. But as she carried the bundle home, the wind caught the loose stalks, scattering them everywhere.  

Now Catherine was truly distressed. "Oh dear, oh dear," she muttered. "First the bacon, now the wheat—what else can go wrong?"  

Just then, she remembered that they had a fine cheese in the pantry. *Surely Frederick will be pleased with cheese and bread!* she thought. But when she returned home and opened the pantry, she found that mice had nibbled holes in the cheese.  

Catherine sat down and wept. "Everything is ruined! What shall I do?"  

At that moment, Frederick returned from the fields, hungry and expecting a warm meal. When he saw Catherine in tears, he asked, "What is the matter, my dear?"  

Between sobs, Catherine told him everything—how the dog had stolen the bacon, how the wind had scattered the wheat, and how the mice had spoiled the cheese.  

Frederick sighed deeply. Then, to Catherine's surprise, he began to laugh. "Oh, Catherine, Catherine," he said, shaking his head. "You mean well, but you must learn to be more careful!"  

And so, instead of scolding her, Frederick took her by the hand and said, "Come, let us go to the inn and have our supper there tonight. Tomorrow, we shall begin anew."  

Catherine, relieved and grateful, smiled through her tears. "Yes, Frederick. And I promise to be more watchful next time."  

And from that day on, Catherine took greater care in her work—though she still had many more amusing mishaps, which Frederick always met with patience and laughter.  

**Moral:** A kind heart and a little patience can turn even the worst mishaps into a tale worth telling.

events.title: The Pursuit and Misadventures with Provisions
detailed_summary: Catherine suggested to Frederick that they should pursue the thieves (the pedlars) to reclaim their stolen gold.
Frederick agreed and instructed her to pack some butter and cheese for their journey.
As they set out, Frederick walked faster, leaving Catherine some distance behind.
Catherine noticed trees along the path that were chafed and damaged by cart wheels.
Feeling compassionate, she decided to use all the butter she had brought to grease the tree trunks, hoping to protect them from further injury.
While she was tending to the trees, one of the cheeses fell from her basket and rolled down a nearby hill, disappearing from sight.
Believing the second cheese could find the first, as it had 'younger legs,' Catherine intentionally rolled it down the hill in the same direction.
She assumed both cheeses would know the way and eventually follow her, so she continued her journey without waiting.
Upon catching up with Frederick, he asked for the food they had packed.
Catherine presented him with only dry bread, explaining she had used the butter to grease the trees and had sent both cheeses rolling down the hill to find each other.
Frederick called her a 'goose' for her silly actions, to which Catherine replied that he had never told her not to do such things.

Catherine stood musing for a while, and at last said to her husband, ‘Hark ye, Frederick, we will soon get the gold back: let us run after the thieves.’ ‘Well, we will try,’ answered he; ‘but take some butter and cheese with you, that we may have something to eat by the way.’ ‘Very well,’ said she; and they set out: and as Frederick walked the fastest, he left his wife some way behind. ‘It does not matter,’ thought she: ‘when we turn back, I shall be so much nearer home than he.’
Presently she came to the top of a hill, down the side of which there was a road so narrow that the cart wheels always chafed the trees on each side as they passed. ‘Ah, see now,’ said she, ‘how they have bruised and wounded those poor trees; they will never get well.’ So she took pity on them, and made use of the butter to grease them all, so that the wheels might not hurt them so much. While she was doing this kind office one of her cheeses fell out of the basket, and rolled down the hill. Catherine looked, but could not see where it had gone; so she said, ‘Well, I suppose the other will go the same way and find you; he has younger legs than I have.’ Then she rolled the other cheese after it; and away it went, nobody knows where, down the hill. But she said she supposed that they knew the road, and would follow her, and she could not stay there all day waiting for them.
At last she overtook Frederick, who desired her to give him something to eat. Then she gave him the dry bread. ‘Where are the butter and cheese?’ said he. ‘Oh!’ answered she, ‘I used the butter to grease those poor trees that the wheels chafed so: and one of the cheeses ran away so I sent the other after it to find it, and I suppose they are both on the road together somewhere.’ ‘What a goose you are to do such silly things!’ said the husband. ‘How can you say so?’ said she; ‘I am sure you never told me not.’

events.title: Securing the House by Carrying Its Door
detailed_summary: After their meager meal of dry bread, Frederick asked Catherine if she had locked the house door securely before they left.
Catherine admitted she had not, reasoning that he hadn't explicitly told her to do so.
Frederick then sent her back home to lock the door and to bring along something more to eat.
On her way, Catherine decided that Frederick might not want more butter and cheese and opted instead to bring a bag of fine nuts and a bottle of vinegar, items she had observed him consuming before.
Upon reaching their house, she bolted the back door as instructed.
However, for the front door, she reasoned that the safest course of action, in line with Frederick's desire to 'lock the door,' was to take it with her entirely.
She therefore removed the front door from its hinges and carried it along as she returned to Frederick.
When she met Frederick, she proudly presented the door, suggesting he could now keep it under his personal watch.
Frederick was utterly dismayed by this interpretation, exclaiming about her 'cleverness' and how removing the door left the house completely vulnerable.
He then declared that as a consequence of her actions, she would have to carry the door herself.

Catherine agreed to carry the door but stated that the combined weight of the door, nuts, and vinegar would be too much. She proposed fastening the nuts and vinegar to the door, a suggestion to which Frederick raised no objection.

events.title: Accidental Recapture of Gold Through a Series of Mishaps
detailed_summary: Frederick and Catherine continued into the woods to search for the thieves but couldn't find them. As night fell, they climbed a tree to rest.
The very thieves they were seeking coincidentally set up camp and made a fire directly beneath the tree where Frederick and Catherine were hidden.
Frederick attempted to drive the thieves away by dropping stones on their heads from above.
The thieves, unaware of Frederick and Catherine's presence, merely commented that it must be morning and the wind was shaking fir-apples from the trees.
Catherine, who was carrying the heavy door on her shoulder with the nuts and vinegar attached, grew very tired. She mistakenly believed the nuts were the main source of the weight.
She informed Frederick she had to drop the nuts. Despite his warning that it would reveal their presence, she insisted and let them fall.
The nuts rattled down, leading one of the thieves to remark that it was hailing.
A short time later, still feeling the door's oppressive weight, Catherine whispered to Frederick that she must now throw down the vinegar.
Frederick again pleaded with her not to, fearing discovery, but Catherine was resolute and poured the vinegar down.
The thieves below simply commented on the unexpectedly heavy dew.
Finally, Catherine realized it was the door itself that was so heavy. She told Frederick she had to drop it.
He begged her not to, certain it would expose them, but Catherine let the door go. It crashed down onto the thieves with a tremendous clatter.
Terrified by the noise and the falling door, the thieves cried 'Murder!' and fled as fast as they could, abandoning all the stolen gold.
Frederick and Catherine then climbed down from the tree and found all their money recovered.

Scarcely were they up, than who should come by but the very rogues they were looking for. They were in truth great rascals, and belonged to that class of people who find things before they are lost; they were tired; so they sat down and made a fire under the very tree where Frederick and Catherine were. Frederick slipped down on the other side, and picked up some stones. Then he climbed up again, and tried to hit the thieves on the head with them: but they only said, ‘It must be near morning, for the wind shakes the fir-apples down.’

A little while after, Catherine thought the door was still very heavy: so she whispered to Frederick, ‘I must throw the vinegar down.’ ‘Pray don’t,’ answered he, ‘it will discover us.’ ‘I can’t help that,’ said she, ‘go it must.’ So she poured all the vinegar down; and the thieves said, ‘What a heavy dew there is!’
At last it popped into Catherine’s head that it was the door itself that was so heavy all the time: so she whispered, ‘Frederick, I must throw the door down soon.’ But he begged and prayed her not to do so, for he was sure it would betray them. ‘Here goes, however,’ said she: and down went the door with such a clatter upon the thieves, that they cried out ‘Murder!’ and not knowing what was coming, ran away as fast as they could, and left all the gold. So when Frederick and Catherine came down, there they found all their money safe and sound.

It was the middle of winter, when the broad flakes of snow were falling around, that the queen of a country many thousand miles off sat working at her window. The frame of the window was made of fine black ebony, and as she sat looking out upon the snow, she pricked her finger, and three drops of blood fell upon it. Then she gazed thoughtfully upon the red drops that sprinkled the white snow, and said, ‘Would that my little daughter may be as white as that snow, as red as that blood, and as black as this ebony windowframe!’ And so the little girl really did grow up; her skin was as white as snow, her cheeks as rosy as the blood, and her hair as black as ebony; and she was called Snowdrop.
But this queen died; and the king soon married another wife, who became queen, and was very beautiful, but so vain that she could not bear to think that anyone could be handsomer than she was. She had a fairy looking-glass, to which she used to go, and then she would gaze upon herself in it, and say:
‘Tell me, glass, tell me true!
  Of all the ladies in the land,
  Who is fairest, tell me, who?’
And the glass had always answered:
‘Thou, queen, art the fairest in all the land.’

Everything inside the cottage is well-kept and orderly.
A white cloth is spread on the table, set with seven small plates, seven little loaves, seven small glasses containing wine, and seven sets of knives and forks, all neatly arranged.
Against the wall, there are seven small beds.
Feeling very hungry, she takes a small piece from each loaf and sips a tiny amount of wine from each glass.
After eating and drinking, she decides to lie down and rest.
She tries all the little beds; one is too long, another too short, until finally, the seventh bed suits her perfectly, and there she lies down and falls asleep.

By and by in came the masters of the cottage. Now they were seven little dwarfs, that lived among the mountains, and dug and searched for gold. They lighted up their seven lamps, and saw at once that all was not right. The first said, ‘Who has been sitting on my stool?’ The second, ‘Who has been eating off my plate?’ The third, ‘Who has been picking my bread?’ The fourth, ‘Who has been meddling with my spoon?’ The fifth, ‘Who has been handling my fork?’ The sixth, ‘Who has been cutting with my knife?’ The seventh, ‘Who has been drinking my wine?’ Then the first looked round and said, ‘Who has been lying on my bed?’ And the rest came running to him, and everyone cried out that somebody had been upon his bed. But the seventh saw Snowdrop, and called all his brethren to come and see her; and they cried out with wonder and astonishment and brought their lamps to look at her, and said, ‘Good heavens! what a lovely child she is!’ And they were very glad to see her, and took care not to wake her; and the seventh dwarf slept an hour with each of the other dwarfs in turn, till the night was gone.
In the morning Snowdrop told them all her story; and they pitied her, and said if she would keep all things in order, and cook and wash and knit and spin for them, she might stay where she was, and they would take good care of her. Then they went out all day long to their work, seeking for gold and silver in the mountains: but Snowdrop was left at home; and they warned her, and said, ‘The queen will soon find out where you are, so take care and let no one in.’

detailed_summary: The queen, under the impression that Snowdrop is dead, believes herself to be the most beautiful woman in the land and consults her mirror.
The mirror, however, reveals that the queen is the fairest in her immediate vicinity, but Snowdrop is hiding with the seven dwarfs over the hills and is far lovelier.

The disguised queen offers laces and bobbins of all colors.
Snowdrop, thinking the old woman seems kind, decides to let her in.
The old woman comments on how poorly Snowdrop's stays are laced and offers to lace them properly with one of her new, nice laces.
Snowdrop, suspecting no ill intent, stands before the old woman, who quickly and tightly pulls the lace, causing Snowdrop to lose her breath and fall as if dead.
The spiteful queen, believing Snowdrop's beauty finished, departs for home.
In the evening, the seven dwarfs return and are greatly grieved to find Snowdrop motionless on the ground.
They lift her, discover the constricting lace, cut it, and Snowdrop soon begins to breathe and revives.
The dwarfs then identify the old woman as the queen herself and warn Snowdrop again not to let anyone in when they are absent.

Meantime the queen went home to her glass, and shook with rage when she read the very same answer as before; and she said, ‘Snowdrop shall die, if it cost me my life.’ So she went by herself into her chamber, and got ready a poisoned apple: the outside looked very rosy and tempting, but whoever tasted it was sure to die. Then she dressed herself up as a peasant’s wife, and travelled over the hills to the dwarfs’ cottage, and knocked at the door; but Snowdrop put her head out of the window and said, ‘I dare not let anyone in, for the dwarfs have told me not.’ ‘Do as you please,’ said the old woman, ‘but at any rate take this pretty apple; I will give it you.’ ‘No,’ said Snowdrop, ‘I dare not take it.’ ‘You silly girl!’ answered the other, ‘what are you afraid of? Do you think it is poisoned? Come! do you eat one part, and I will eat the other.’ Now the apple was so made up that one side was good, though the other side was poisoned. Then Snowdrop was much tempted to taste, for the apple looked so very nice; and when she saw the old woman eat, she could wait no longer. But she had scarcely put the piece into her mouth, when she fell down dead upon the ground. ‘This time nothing will save thee,’ said the queen; and she went home to her glass, and at last it said:
‘Thou, queen, art the fairest of all the fair.’
And then her wicked heart was glad, and as happy as such a heart could be.

events.title: Snowdrop's Apparent Death and Vigil in the Glass Coffin
detailed_summary: When evening arrived and the dwarfs returned home, they found Snowdrop lying on the ground; no breath came from her lips, and they feared she was quite dead.
They lifted her, combed her hair, and washed her face with wine and water, but all their efforts were in vain, as the little girl appeared entirely lifeless.
They laid her down upon a bier and all seven watched over and lamented her for three entire days.
After three days, they considered burying her, but her cheeks were still rosy, and her face looked just as it did when she was alive.
Therefore, they decided they would never bury her in the cold ground.
Instead, they constructed a coffin of glass, so they could always look at her, and inscribed upon it in golden letters her name and that she was a king's daughter.
The coffin was set among the hills, and one of the dwarfs always remained by it to watch.
Birds of the air also came to mourn Snowdrop; first an owl, then a raven, and finally a dove, all sat by her side.

events.title: The Cook's Deceit, the Child's Abduction, and the Queen's Unjust Imprisonment
detailed_summary: The queen habitually took her young son to a garden with wild animals, where she would bathe in a clear stream.
During one such visit, while the queen slept with the child in her arms, the old cook, aware of the child's wish-granting ability, abducted him.
To frame the queen, the cook slaughtered a hen and stained her apron and dress with its blood.
He then falsely reported to the king that wild beasts had snatched the child.
The king, convinced by the blood evidence, reacted with fury, ordering the queen to be imprisoned in a high, dark tower for seven years without food or water, expecting her to perish.
However, two angels, appearing as white doves, miraculously delivered food to the queen twice a day, sustaining her throughout her seven-year confinement.

events.title: The Cook's Exploitation, the Maiden's Mercy, and the Cook's Canine Transformation
detailed_summary: The cook, fearing the child's wishing power could expose his villainy, departed from the palace.
He located the boy, who was now old enough to speak, and prompted him to wish for a magnificent palace with a garden, which instantly materialized.
Sometime later, the cook suggested the boy wish for a beautiful girl as a companion, leading to the immediate appearance of a lovely maiden.
The boy and the maiden developed a close bond, playing together and loving each other, while the old cook enjoyed a life of leisure, hunting like a nobleman.
Concerned that the prince might eventually wish to reunite with his father, thus putting the cook in danger, the cook devised a plan.
He privately instructed the maiden to kill the sleeping boy that night by plunging a knife into his heart and to bring him the boy's heart and tongue, threatening her life if she failed.
The next day, when the cook returned, the maiden had not complied, questioning why she should harm an innocent boy.
The cook reiterated his threat, stating her life depended on obedience.
After the cook left, the maiden had a young deer (hind) killed, took its heart and tongue, and placed them on a plate to deceive him.
She instructed the boy to feign sleep in his bed, covered by clothes.
When the cook entered and demanded the boy's heart and tongue, the maiden presented the plate, but the prince suddenly threw off his covers.

The prince confronted the cook, questioning his murderous intent, and then pronounced his sentence: the cook would transform into a black poodle with a gold collar and be forced to eat burning coals until flames erupted from his throat.
Upon these words, the cook was instantly changed into a poodle and compelled by other cooks to eat live coals until his throat burst into flames.

After a while the cook said to him: ‘It is not well for you to be so alone, wish for a pretty girl as a companion.’ Then the king’s son wished for one, and she immediately stood before him, and was more beautiful than any painter could have painted her. The two played together, and loved each other with all their hearts, and the old cook went out hunting like a nobleman. The thought occurred to him, however, that the king’s son might some day wish to be with his father, and thus bring him into great peril. So he went out and took the maiden aside, and said: ‘Tonight when the boy is asleep, go to his bed and plunge this knife into his heart, and bring me his heart and tongue, and if you do not do it, you shall lose your life.’ Thereupon he went away, and when he returned next day she had not done it, and said: ‘Why should I shed the blood of an innocent boy who has never harmed anyone?’ The cook once more said: ‘If you do not do it, it shall cost you your own life.’ When he had gone away, she had a little hind brought to her, and ordered her to be killed, and took her heart and tongue, and laid them on a plate, and when she saw the old man coming, she said to the boy: ‘Lie down in your bed, and draw the clothes over you.’ Then the wicked wretch came in and said: ‘Where are the boy’s heart and tongue?’ The girl reached the plate to him, but the king’s son threw off the quilt, and said: ‘You old sinner, why did you want to kill me? Now will I pronounce thy sentence. You shall become a black poodle and have a gold collar round your neck, and shall eat burning coals, till the flames burst forth from your throat.’ And when he had spoken these words, the old man was changed into a poodle dog, and had a gold collar round his neck, and the cooks were ordered to bring up some live coals, and these he ate, until the flames broke forth from his throat.

The massive haul of game was loaded onto sixty carts and transported back to the king.
This allowed the king, after many years, to finally serve game at his table.

events.title: Elsie's Betrothal and an Ominous Vision in the Cellar
detailed_summary: - Elsie's parents expressed their desire for her to get married.
- A suitor named Hans appeared, specifying that his future wife, Elsie, must be exceptionally intelligent.
- Elsie's father asserted her good sense, while her mother made hyperbolic claims about her perceptive abilities, such as detecting wind and hearing flies cough.
- Hans reiterated that he would only marry her if she was truly smart.
- During dinner, Elsie was instructed by her mother to go to the cellar to fetch beer.
- Elsie took a pitcher and, to make the time pass quickly, tapped the lid as she descended.
- In the cellar, she arranged a chair by the barrel to avoid straining herself while drawing the beer.
- As the beer flowed, she scanned her surroundings and noticed a pick-axe left precariously above her by masons.

She was known throughout the village for her sharp wit and quick thinking, though some whispered that her cleverness often led her into trouble. Between sobs, Elsie explained her fears. "Mother, just think! If Hans and I have a son, and he comes down here to draw beer, that pick-axe will fall and kill him!"  

The mother, struck by the horror of this imagined tragedy, clutched her chest and cried, "Oh, you are right, my clever Elsie! What a terrible thing that would be!" And she, too, began to weep.  

Soon, Elsie’s father came in from the fields, wondering why his wife and daughter were crying in the cellar. When they told him of the dreadful fate that awaited their future grandchild, he shook his head gravely. "Aye, the pick-axe is loose," he admitted. "It could happen just as you say!" And he, too, joined in the weeping.  

The three of them sat on the cellar steps, mourning the poor boy who had not yet been born, when Hans arrived to visit Elsie. He stopped in the doorway, bewildered by the sight before him. "What has happened?" he asked. "Why are you all crying?"  

Elsie lifted her tear-streaked face. "Oh, Hans! If we marry and have a son, and he grows up and comes to draw beer, the pick-axe will fall and kill him!"  

Hans, after a moment of stunned silence, scratched his head. "Well," he said slowly, "that does sound very sad. But—has the boy been born yet?"  

Elsie blinked. "No."  

"Has the pick-axe fallen yet?"  

"No."  

"Then why are we crying?"  

The three of them looked at one another, their tears drying as they considered Hans’s simple logic. Elsie’s father coughed and stood up. "Well, now that you mention it, perhaps we’ve been a bit hasty."  

Elsie’s mother nodded. "Yes, yes, no need to cry over a pick-axe that hasn’t fallen and a boy who doesn’t exist!"  

Clever Elsie wiped her eyes and smiled at Hans. "You’re right, Hans. I suppose I was being silly."  

Hans grinned. "Then let’s go upstairs and have some beer—carefully!"  

And so, the four of them left the cellar, laughing at their foolishness, and the pick-axe remained hanging harmlessly on the wall, waiting for a danger that would never come.

events.title: Hans's Curious Approval and the Unlikely Wedding
detailed_summary: - Hans, the bridegroom, waited alone upstairs for a considerable time.
- Believing the others might be waiting for him below, he decided to go to the cellar to see what was happening.
- Upon descending, he found all five individuals—Elsie, the maid, the boy, Elsie's mother, and Elsie's father—loudly screaming and lamenting.
- Hans inquired about the cause of their misfortune.
- Elsie explained her fear: if they married and had a child who was later sent to the cellar for a drink, the pick-axe might fall and kill him.

- Impressed by her perceived cleverness, he affirmed he would marry her, took her hand, and they went upstairs and were wed.

events.title: The Jingling Bells and Elsie's Existential Crisis
detailed_summary: - Upon finding Elsie asleep, Hans quickly returned home and brought a fowler's net adorned with little bells, which he hung around her while she continued to sleep.
- He then ran back home, shut the house door, sat in his chair, and resumed working.
- When it was quite dark, Clever Elsie finally awoke.
- As she stood up, she was surrounded by a jingling sound, with bells ringing at her every step.
- This alarmed her and made her deeply uncertain about her own identity, causing her to wonder aloud if she was truly Clever Elsie.
- Unable to resolve this doubt, she decided to go home and ask, believing they would know.
- She ran to her house door but found it shut; she knocked on the window and called out to Hans, asking if Elsie was inside.
- Hans replied from within that Elsie was indeed inside.
- This terrified Elsie, convincing her that she was not herself.
- She then went to another door, but the people there, hearing the jingling bells, refused to open it, leaving her unable to find entry anywhere.
- Consequently, she fled the village, and her whereabouts thereafter remained unknown.

events.title: The Servant's Departure with Meager Pay
detailed_summary: A loyal servant, after three years of dedicated but unpaid labor for his master, finally requested the wages he was owed.
The master, characterized as a severe miser, recognized his servant's simple nature and decided to exploit it, giving him only three pence – one penny for each year of service.
The naive servant, believing this to be a substantial amount of money, felt a sense of newfound wealth and freedom.
He resolved to abandon his difficult life of hard work and poor sustenance, deciding instead to travel the world and enjoy himself.
With this resolution, he placed his meager earnings into his purse and embarked on his journey, wandering through the countryside.

events.title: Encounter with the Dwarf and the Granting of Three Wishes

Moved by pity, the kind-hearted countryman gave the dwarf all of his money.

As a reward for his generosity and honest heart, the dwarf granted him three wishes: a bow that would never miss its target, a fiddle whose music would compel anyone who heard it to dance, and the ability to have any request he made granted.
The dwarf then provided the magical bow and fiddle to the countryman and departed.

events.title: The Countryman Outwits a Miser Using His Magical Gifts
detailed_summary: The countryman continued his journey, his spirits even higher than before, and soon encountered an old miser.
Nearby, a thrush sang joyfully from the top of a tree, and the miser expressed a strong desire to possess the bird, claiming he would pay a great sum for it.
The countryman offered to retrieve the bird and, using his magical bow, shot the thrush, causing it to fall into a thorny bush at the tree's base.
As the miser ventured into the dense bush to find the bird, the countryman began to play his magical fiddle.
The music irresistibly forced the miser to dance and leap among the thorns, which tore his clothes to shreds and left him scratched and bleeding.
The miser, in agony, begged the countryman to stop the music, pleading his innocence and asking what he had done to deserve such treatment.
The countryman retorted that the miser was merely receiving his due for having exploited many poor people, and he continued to play.

Desperate, the miser started offering money for his release, gradually increasing his bids as the countryman played faster tunes, until he finally offered a hundred florins – money he had recently acquired by cheating someone.
Seeing this substantial sum, the countryman agreed, took the purse, ceased playing, and contentedly resumed his travels.

The miser crept into the bush to find it; but directly he had got into the middle, his companion took up his fiddle and played away, and the miser began to dance and spring about, capering higher and higher in the air. The thorns soon began to tear his clothes till they all hung in rags about him, and he himself was all scratched and wounded, so that the blood ran down. ‘Oh, for heaven’s sake!’ cried the miser, ‘Master! master! pray let the fiddle alone. What have I done to deserve this?’ ‘Thou hast shaved many a poor soul close enough,’ said the other; ‘thou art only meeting thy reward’: so he played up another tune. Then the miser began to beg and promise, and offered money for his liberty; but he did not come up to the musician’s price for some time, and he danced him along brisker and brisker, and the miser bid higher and higher, till at last he offered a round hundred of florins that he had in his purse, and had just gained by cheating some poor fellow. When the countryman saw so much money, he said, ‘I will agree to your proposal.’ So he took the purse, put up his fiddle, and travelled on very pleased with his bargain.

And the snow fell and spread a beautiful white covering over the grave; but by the time the spring came, and the sun had melted it away again, her father had married another wife. This new wife had two daughters of her own, that she brought home with her; they were fair in face but foul at heart, and it was now a sorry time for the poor little girl. ‘What does the good-for-nothing want in the parlour?’ said they; ‘they who would eat bread should first earn it; away with the kitchen-maid!’ Then they took away her fine clothes, and gave her an old grey frock to put on, and laughed at her, and turned her into the kitchen.
There she was forced to do hard work; to rise early before daylight, to bring the water, to make the fire, to cook and to wash. Besides that, the sisters plagued her in all sorts of ways, and laughed at her. In the evening when she was tired, she had no bed to lie down on, but was made to lie by the hearth among the ashes; and as this, of course, made her always dusty and dirty, they called her Ashputtel.

When Ashputtel pleaded intensely, the stepmother, intending to dissuade her, set a new condition: Ashputtel must pick two dishes of peas from the ashes in one hour to be allowed to go.
The stepmother thought this would finally rid her of Ashputtel's pestering, so she poured two dishes of peas into the ashes.

But when they had broken open the door they found no one within; and as they came back into the house, Ashputtel was lying, as she always did, in her dirty frock by the ashes, and her dim little lamp was burning in the chimney. For she had run as quickly as she could through the pigeon-house and on to the hazel-tree, and had there taken off her beautiful clothes, and put them beneath the tree, that the bird might carry them away, and had lain down again amid the ashes in her little grey frock.

Then both the sisters were overjoyed to hear it; for they had beautiful feet, and had no doubt that they could wear the golden slipper. The eldest went first into the room where the slipper was, and wanted to try it on, and the mother stood by. But her great toe could not go into it, and the shoe was altogether much too small for her. Then the mother gave her a knife, and said, ‘Never mind, cut it off; when you are queen you will not care about toes; you will not want to walk.’ So the silly girl cut off her great toe, and thus squeezed on the shoe, and went to the king’s son. Then he took her for his bride, and set her beside him on his horse, and rode away with her homewards.
But on their way home they had to pass by the hazel-tree that Ashputtel had planted; and on the branch sat a little dove singing:
‘Back again! back again! look to the shoe!
  The shoe is too small, and not made for you!
  Prince! prince! look again for thy bride,
  For she’s not the true one that sits by thy side.’
Then the prince got down and looked at her foot; and he saw, by the blood that streamed from it, what a trick she had played him. So he turned his horse round, and brought the false bride back to her home, and said, ‘This is not the right bride; let the other sister try and put on the slipper.’ Then she went into the room and got her foot into the shoe, all but the heel, which was too large. But her mother squeezed it in till the blood came, and took her to the king’s son: and he set her as his bride by his side on his horse, and rode away with her.
But when they came to the hazel-tree the little dove sat there still, and sang:
‘Back again! back again! look to the shoe!
  The shoe is too small, and not made for you!
  Prince! prince! look again for thy bride,
  For she’s not the true one that sits by thy side.’
Then he looked down, and saw that the blood streamed so much from the shoe, that her white stockings were quite red. So he turned his horse and brought her also back again.

It appeared that no secrets were kept from him, as if information about the most confidential matters was mysteriously conveyed to him.

This dish was always presented covered, and its contents were unknown even to the servant who delivered it.
The king would only remove the cover and consume its contents when he was entirely by himself, ensuring the nature of this meal remained a complete mystery to everyone else.

All the onlookers felt sorrow for the handsome youth as they departed, leaving him isolated by the sea.

They identified themselves as the three young ravens whom he had saved from starvation.
They explained that once they had grown large and strong, they heard about his quest for the Golden Apple.
Consequently, they had flown across the sea to the very end of the world, where the Tree of Life stands, and had brought back the apple for him.
The youth, filled with immense joy, began his journey homeward.
He presented the Golden Apple to the king's beautiful daughter, who now had no further excuses to refuse him.
Together, they cut the Apple of Life in two and ate it.

Two kings’ sons once upon a time went into the world to seek their fortunes; but they soon fell into a wasteful foolish way of living, so that they could not return home again. Then their brother, who was a little insignificant dwarf, went out to seek for his brothers: but when he had found them they only laughed at him, to think that he, who was so young and simple, should try to travel through the world, when they, who were so much wiser, had been unable to get on. However, they all set out on their journey together, and came at last to an ant-hill. The two elder brothers would have pulled it down, in order to see how the poor ants in their fright would run about and carry off their eggs. But the little dwarf said, ‘Let the poor things enjoy themselves, I will not suffer you to trouble them.’
So on they went, and came to a lake where many many ducks were swimming about. The two brothers wanted to catch two, and roast them. But the dwarf said, ‘Let the poor things enjoy themselves, you shall not kill them.’ Next they came to a bees’-nest in a hollow tree, and there was so much honey that it ran down the trunk; and the two brothers wanted to light a fire under the tree and kill the bees, so as to get their honey. But the dwarf held them back, and said, ‘Let the pretty insects enjoy themselves, I cannot let you burn them.’

Presently the fruit became round and firm, and she was glad and at peace; but when they were fully ripe she picked the berries and ate eagerly of them, and then she grew sad and ill. events.title: The Boy's Transformation into a Bird at the Juniper Tree
detailed_summary: Little Marleen went to her room, took her finest silk handkerchief from her drawer, and used it to gather all the bones from under the table, weeping all the while.
She carried them outside and laid them in the green grass beneath the juniper tree.

The juniper tree then began to stir, its branches moving back and forth, apart and then together, as if joyfully clapping.
A mist enveloped the tree, and within the mist, a fire-like burning appeared.
Out of this fire, a beautiful bird emerged, soaring high into the air, singing magnificently.
When the bird was no longer visible, the juniper tree stood as it was before, and both the silk handkerchief and the bones had vanished.
Little Marleen then felt as lighthearted and happy as if her brother were still alive.
She returned to the house, sat down cheerfully at the table, and ate.

events.title: The Bird Sings for the Millers and Receives a Millstone
detailed_summary: After finishing its song, the bird flew away, carrying the gold chain in its right claw and the red shoes in its left, heading towards a mill.
The mill was operating with a 'Click clack' sound, while inside, twenty of the miller's men were hewing a stone, their tools making a 'Hick hack' sound.
The bird landed on a lime-tree in front of the mill and began to sing its song.

As it sang each line detailing its mother's crime, its father's grief, and its sister's love and care for its remains under the juniper tree, the miller's men progressively stopped their work to listen.
Eventually, only one man was left working, and then he too stopped and looked up.
This last man praised the bird's beautiful song and asked to hear it again.
The bird replied that it doesn't sing twice for nothing and requested the millstone in exchange.
The man said if it were his alone, the bird could have it, and the other millers agreed, saying the bird could have it if it sang again.
The bird descended, and all twenty millers worked together to lift the millstone with a beam.
The bird then put its head through the hole in the stone, wearing it like a collar, and flew back to the tree, where it sang its song once more.

events.text_segment:
There were two brothers who were both soldiers; the one was rich and the other poor. The poor man thought he would try to better himself; so, pulling off his red coat, he became a gardener, and dug his ground well, and sowed turnips.
When the seed came up, there was one plant bigger than all the rest; and it kept getting larger and larger, and seemed as if it would never cease growing; so that it might have been called the prince of turnips for there never was such a one seen before, and never will again. At last it was so big that it filled a cart, and two oxen could hardly draw it; and the gardener knew not what in the world to do with it, nor whether it would be a blessing or a curse to him. One day he said to himself, ‘What shall I do with it? if I sell it, it will bring no more than another; and for eating, the little turnips are better than this; the best thing perhaps is to carry it and give it to the king as a mark of respect.’
Then he yoked his oxen, and drew the turnip to the court, and gave it to the king. ‘What a wonderful thing!’ said the king; ‘I have seen many strange things, but such a monster as this I never saw. Where did you get the seed? or is it only your good luck? If so, you are a true child of fortune.’ ‘Ah, no!’ answered the gardener, ‘I am no child of fortune; I am a poor soldier, who never could get enough to live upon; so I laid aside my red coat, and set to work, tilling the ground. I have a brother, who is rich, and your majesty knows him well, and all the world knows him; but because I am poor, everybody forgets me.’
The king then took pity on him, and said, ‘You shall be poor no longer. I will give you so much that you shall be even richer than your brother.’ Then he gave him gold and lands and flocks, and made him so rich that his brother’s fortune could not at all be compared with his.

One day, the poor brother said to the rich one, "Why should I remain in this wretched state when you have so much? Surely, you could spare me a little to ease my burdens."

The old man smiled. "Then take this little drum. When you beat it, all who hear its sound will dance until you command them to stop. But use it wisely, for greed brings ruin."

events.text_segment:
The student listened to all this and wondered much; at last he said, ‘Blessed be the day and hour when I found you; cannot you contrive to let me into the sack for a little while?’ Then the other answered, as if very unwillingly, ‘A little space I may allow thee to sit here, if thou wilt reward me well and entreat me kindly; but thou must tarry yet an hour below, till I have learnt some little matters that are yet unknown to me.’
So the student sat himself down and waited a while; but the time hung heavy upon him, and he begged earnestly that he might ascend forthwith, for his thirst for knowledge was great. Then the other pretended to give way, and said, ‘Thou must let the sack of wisdom descend, by untying yonder cord, and then thou shalt enter.’ So the student let him down, opened the sack, and set him free. ‘Now then,’ cried he, ‘let me ascend quickly.’ As he began to put himself into the sack heels first, ‘Wait a while,’ said the gardener, ‘that is not the way.’ Then he pushed him in head first, tied up the sack, and soon swung up the searcher after wisdom dangling in the air. ‘How is it with thee, friend?’ said he, ‘dost thou not feel that wisdom comes unto thee? Rest there in peace, till thou art a wiser man than thou wert.’
So saying, he trotted off on the student’s nag, and left the poor fellow to gather wisdom till somebody should come and let him down.

Hans’s eyes gleamed. "I’ll trade you my silver for it!"  

The man pretended to think it over, though he was already reaching for the silver. "Well… I suppose I could part with him for such a generous offer."  

And so, Hans handed over his silver and led the horse away, proud as a king.  

### **The Second Trade**  

But Hans had not gone far when he met a farmer driving a fat cow.  

"My, what a splendid horse!" the farmer said.  

"Indeed!" Hans agreed. "But a cow would be far more useful—milk every day, and cheese besides!"  

The farmer stroked his chin. "Well, if you’re offering…"  

Before long, Hans was trotting off with the cow, leaving the horse behind.  

### **The Third Trade**  

Next, Hans met a shepherd with a sturdy pig.  

"A fine cow you have there," the shepherd said.  

Hans nodded. "But a pig! Think of the bacon, the sausages!"  

The shepherd grinned. "A fair trade, then?"  

And so, the cow was exchanged for the pig.  

### **The Fourth Trade**  

Not long after, Hans came upon a gooseherd with a plump white goose under his arm.  

"Ah, a pig is well and good," the gooseherd said, "but a goose! Why, it lays golden eggs!"  

Hans’s eyes widened. "Golden eggs, you say?"  

"Every morning!" the gooseherd lied smoothly.  

Without another thought, Hans handed over the pig and took the goose.  

### **The Fifth Trade**  

As the sun began to set, Hans met a miller’s boy carrying a heavy grindstone.  

"That’s a fine goose," the boy said. "But a grindstone—now that’s useful! You can sharpen knives, crush grain—why, it’s worth its weight in gold!"  

Hans scratched his head. "I suppose a grindstone would last longer than a goose…"  

And so, the goose was traded for the grindstone.  

### **The Last Trade**  

By now, Hans was weary, and the grindstone was heavy. As he trudged along, he came to a well. Thirsty, he leaned over to drink—but the grindstone slipped from his hands and tumbled into the depths with a mighty splash!  

Hans stared into the well, then burst out laughing. "Well! Now I’m free of that burden at last!"  

And with a light heart, he skipped all the way home.  

### **The Moral**  

When Hans returned empty-handed, Farmer Korbes shook his head. "Hans, you fool, you’ve traded away everything for nothing!"  

But Hans only smiled. "Ah, but I had a grand adventure, and now I’m as free as a bird!"  

And so, though some called him foolish, Hans remained happy—for he valued joy more than riches.  

**The End.**

After a year with the first master, the son returned home, having only learned to understand the barking of dogs.
The count, dismayed by this singular, unconventional skill, sent his son to a different master in another town.
Following another year of study, the son came back, this time reporting that he had learned to understand what birds say.
The father became extremely angry, berating his son for wasting time and learning nothing of practical value, and threatened to disown him if he failed with a third master.
The youth spent a year with a third master and returned, stating he had learned what frogs croak.
Overcome with fury, the father declared the youth was no longer his son, ordered his servants to take him into the forest, and kill him.
The servants, feeling pity for the youth, could not bring themselves to kill him and instead let him go, deceiving the count by presenting parts from a deer as proof of his death.

Those who heard this were overjoyed, and the lord promised to adopt the youth as his son if he successfully retrieved the treasure.
The youth descended into the tower again, performed the necessary actions as he understood them, and brought out a chest filled with gold.
Consequently, the howling of the wild dogs ceased, they vanished, and the land was relieved of its affliction.

events.title: The Brothers' Reunion and Initial Skill Demonstrations
detailed_summary: Four years later, as agreed, the four brothers reconvened at the crossroads.
They greeted each other warmly and journeyed together to their father's home.
Upon arrival, they recounted their experiences and the unique crafts each had mastered.
One day, while sitting under a tall tree, their father expressed a desire to witness their skills.
He looked up and asked his second son, the star-gazer, to identify the number of eggs in a chaffinch's nest at the treetop.
The star-gazer used his glass, looked up, and confirmed there were five eggs.
The father then instructed his eldest son, the thief, to retrieve the eggs without alerting the bird sitting on them.
The thief skillfully climbed the tree and brought the five eggs to his father from under the unsuspecting bird, which remained undisturbed.
The father then placed one egg on each corner of a table and the fifth in the center, and directed the huntsman to slice all five eggs in two with a single shot.
The huntsman took his bow and, with one shot, accurately struck all five eggs as requested.

After the space of four years, at the time agreed upon, the four brothers met at the four cross-roads; and having welcomed each other, set off towards their father’s home, where they told him all that had happened to them, and how each had learned some craft.
Then, one day, as they were sitting before the house under a very high tree, the father said, ‘I should like to try what each of you can do in this way.’ So he looked up, and said to the second son, ‘At the top of this tree there is a chaffinch’s nest; tell me how many eggs there are in it.’ The star-gazer took his glass, looked up, and said, ‘Five.’ ‘Now,’ said the father to the eldest son, ‘take away the eggs without letting the bird that is sitting upon them and hatching them know anything of what you are doing.’ So the cunning thief climbed up the tree, and brought away to his father the five eggs from under the bird; and it never saw or felt what he was doing, but kept sitting on at its ease. Then the father took the eggs, and put one on each corner of the table, and the fifth in the middle, and said to the huntsman, ‘Cut all the eggs in two pieces at one shot.’ The huntsman took up his bow, and at one shot struck all the five eggs as his father wished.

events.text_segment:
A merchant, who had three daughters, was once setting out upon a journey; but before he went he asked each daughter what gift he should bring back for her. The eldest wished for pearls; the second for jewels; but the third, who was called Lily, said, ‘Dear father, bring me a rose.’ Now it was no easy task to find a rose, for it was the middle of winter; yet as she was his prettiest daughter, and was very fond of flowers, her father said he would try what he could do. So he kissed all three, and bid them goodbye.
And when the time came for him to go home, he had bought pearls and jewels for the two eldest, but he had sought everywhere in vain for the rose; and when he went into any garden and asked for such a thing, the people laughed at him, and asked him whether he thought roses grew in snow. This grieved him very much, for Lily was his dearest child; and as he was journeying home, thinking what he should bring her, he came to a fine castle; and around the castle was a garden, in one half of which it seemed to be summer-time and in the other half winter. On one side the finest flowers were in full bloom, and on the other everything looked dreary and buried in the snow. ‘A lucky hit!’ said he, as he called to his servant, and told him to go to a beautiful bed of roses that was there, and bring him away one of the finest flowers.

events.title: Lily's Seven-Year Ordeal and Celestial Assistance
detailed_summary: Following his statement, the prince, now a dove, flew out the door, and poor Lily began her pursuit, guided intermittently by a falling white feather that indicated her route.
In this manner, she roamed continuously through the vast world, never looking aside or taking any rest for a period of seven years.
As the seven-year mark approached, she started to feel glad, believing her troubles were nearing an end; yet, relief was still distant.
One day, while traveling, she realized she had missed the white feather, and upon looking up, she could no longer see the dove anywhere.
She thought to herself that no human assistance could now be of use to her.
So, she approached the Sun, explaining its universal reach, and asked if it had seen her white dove.
The Sun replied that it had not seen the dove but offered her a casket, instructing her to open it when her hour of need arrived.
Lily thanked the Sun and continued her journey until evening.
When the Moon rose, she cried out to it, describing its nightly illumination, and asked if it had seen her white dove.
The Moon responded that it could not help her but would give her an egg, advising her to break it when the need arose.
She thanked the Moon and journeyed on until the night-wind began to blow.
She addressed the Night-Wind, noting its pervasive presence, and asked if it had seen her white dove.
The Night-Wind replied that it had not but would consult three other winds.
The East Wind and West Wind subsequently reported they had not seen the dove either.
However, the South Wind stated it had seen the white dove, revealing he had flown to the Red Sea and transformed back into a lion, as the seven years had passed.
The South Wind added that the lion was currently fighting a dragon, which was an enchanted princess attempting to separate him from Lily.
The Night-Wind then offered counsel: Lily should go to the Red Sea, where on the right shore she would find many rods. She was to count them, break off the eleventh, and strike the dragon with it.
This act would grant the lion victory, and both he and the dragon would revert to their true forms.
Afterward, she should look for a griffin by the Red Sea, jump onto its back with her beloved as quickly as possible, and it would transport them across the waters to their home.

The Night-Wind also gave her a nut, instructing her to throw it down when they were halfway across the sea. This would cause a tall nut-tree to spring from the waters, allowing the griffin to rest, as it would otherwise lack the strength for the entire journey; forgetting this would result in them both falling into the sea.

events.text_segment:
This said, he flew out at the door, and poor Lily followed; and every now and then a white feather fell, and showed her the way she was to journey. Thus she went roving on through the wide world, and looked neither to the right hand nor to the left, nor took any rest, for seven years. Then she began to be glad, and thought to herself that the time was fast coming when all her troubles should end; yet repose was still far off, for one day as she was travelling on she missed the white feather, and when she lifted up her eyes she could nowhere see the dove. ‘Now,’ thought she to herself, ‘no aid of man can be of use to me.’ So she went to the sun and said, ‘Thou shinest everywhere, on the hill’s top and the valley’s depth—hast thou anywhere seen my white dove?’ ‘No,’ said the sun, ‘I have not seen it; but I will give thee a casket—open it when thy hour of need comes.’
So she thanked the sun, and went on her way till eventide; and when the moon arose, she cried unto it, and said, ‘Thou shinest through the night, over field and grove—hast thou nowhere seen my white dove?’ ‘No,’ said the moon, ‘I cannot help thee but I will give thee an egg—break it when need comes.’
Then she thanked the moon, and went on till the night-wind blew; and she raised up her voice to it, and said, ‘Thou blowest through every tree and under every leaf—hast thou not seen my white dove?’ ‘No,’ said the night-wind, ‘but I will ask three other winds; perhaps they have seen it.’ Then the east wind and the west wind came, and said they too had not seen it, but the south wind said, ‘I have seen the white dove—he has fled to the Red Sea, and is changed once more into a lion, for the seven years are passed away, and there he is fighting with a dragon; and the dragon is an enchanted princess, who seeks to separate him from you.’ Then the night-wind said, ‘I will give thee counsel. Go to the Red Sea; on the right shore stand many rods—count them, and when thou comest to the eleventh, break it off, and smite the dragon with it; and so the lion will have the victory, and both of them will appear to you in their own forms. Then look round and thou wilt see a griffin, winged like bird, sitting by the Red Sea; jump on to his back with thy beloved one as quickly as possible, and he will carry you over the waters to your home. I will also give thee this nut,’ continued the night-wind. ‘When you are half-way over, throw it down, and out of the waters will immediately spring up a high nut-tree on which the griffin will be able to rest, otherwise he would not have the strength to bear you the whole way; if, therefore, thou dost forget to throw down the nut, he will let you both fall into the sea.’
